turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I was actually trying to see about getting a little advice, you know --

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Advice? I'm supposed to be getting the stock tips from you, Ben. Unless - have you quit your job? They fired you?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You know, dah--

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Actually it's not about work, it's advice about --

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh for crying out loud Ben, you don't mean to tell me that your marriage is going down the drain now --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well, Elena and I have kind of been talking, not really talking, but --

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: -- Your mother, God bless her, stood by me for forty-two years -- we never once contemplated divorce - I assume you're talking here about divorce? The very thought --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But dad, you guys truly hated each other, I mean really hated each --

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: -- Waiter! Where's my cobb salad?  You want advice Ben? If your big brother were still alive I'd have him go out into the back yard and beat some sense into your head. Look kid, you married that woman against my advice --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: -- What advice? You never --

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's besides the point. The point is if I'd had any sense in me I'd have divorced your mother 40 years ago, and that's the truth, and here it is, 1972 --

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: -- 73, and divorce is as easy as paying off a traffic ticket, and for crying out loud, Ben, be a man and just get it over with. I would have if I'd had the chance.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But what?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But I -- well maybe I love her. Elena.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's not the taxes I object to. It's all the fines and penalties.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Alright dad. But you sold the house, you didn't tell anyone, including the IRS, and I'd of certainly liked to have seen if there was any old stuff --

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It was all junk!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh. Elena wanted to know when we could expect you on Thanksgiving. It's just going to be you this year.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ben, I'm going to Florida. I hate Thanksgiving and I hate the cold. I have a new nurse. She's a negro, she weighs three hundred pounds, and I've decided to leave my entire estate to her.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Jesus, Benjamin, you're still as gullible as ever.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: That was a joke? You don't tell jokes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I thought I'd start trying. If you don't mind. But I am going to Florida and I do have a new nurse.

turns.speaker: GORMAN
turns.text: Welcome to the Monkey House has been a seminal influence on me -- hey Benjamin -- give it a try? This stuff will make some sense out of those larger questions.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Thanks for the advice Dave.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Good shit.

turns.speaker: GORMAN
turns.text: Sure is good shit. It's opiated. I had it in my chamber for a while. I was smoking this other --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: It's what?

turns.speaker: GORMAN
turns.text: Don't fret, Benjie, it's --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Darn it, Dave.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: And to think -- they met at a key party of all things.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: A key party?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: You know, it's a California thing. That scuzzy husband of hers dragged her kicking and screaming to one when they were out in L.A. you know, the men put their car keys in a bowl, and then at the end of the evening the women line up and fish them out and go home with whoever's keys they've got. Anyhow that's how she met this Rod person or whatever his name is and he's left his wife and she's packing for California. Irwin is devastated. It's so ironic.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Thank you Janey.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: It was lovely!

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Hello you two. Am I barging in on some kind of religious study group? Elena, you look marvelous. Will I see you and Ben at the Halford's?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I suppose we'll make an appearance.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: And Reverend Edwards? Did you make the list?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, I have to say I don't have much faith that my car keys are still in that bowl. Doesn't seem entirely safe, leaving your car keys around?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Let me.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Thanks, but -- oh, I don't think so. It's been kind of a discouraging evening.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You couldn't have hoped for much better when you came up the walk.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Somehow it was different in my imagination when I thought about it. Actually, I didn't think about it at all, really.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You want coffee or something?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Well, maybe they have one of those filter jobs in the kitchen --

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Look, Elena, the fact that we're neighbors... you know, close friends, well it sort of makes this a little strange, don't you think?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: My husband is probably passed out in the bathroom, or at least he wishes he were. I've been married to him for 17 years and I don't have any intention of going in there to get him... so what I'm proposing is that since your wife has gone off with a boy, and since you are standing here alone, I'm proposing that you and I do what makes sense. Stay warm. Pass some time. That's all.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Now don't make me feel as if I'm being too forward, OK? If you don't --

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What the hey. Let's go for a drive.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Okay. Shall we clean up around here first? Do you think it's all right--

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Nah, that wasn't in the contract.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Things are really rotten at home. You wouldn't believe how rotten. Janey's sick. She's unstable, I guess... it's not the right time to tell you... but that's it -- it's like I can't make her happy, the boys can't make her happy, she just doesn't --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Jim, maybe we should just go. I've got to look in on the kids. Paul is supposed to be coming back in from the city.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Jesus, let me make it up to you -- I can do better than that, honestly --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Well, we can talk about it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's fine. I wouldn't expect you to see it any other way.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Maybe you just need -- look, can you wait here a sec, I need to tidy up -- just a minute, I'll be right back. You'll wait?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Yeah. You?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yes. Well, I guess we can walk from here.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You want to come in, get a cup of coffee -- warm up? I can either walk you home, or you could crash in the guest room.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Sure. Maybe coffee.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Phone's out. I hope the pipe's --

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Hi mom.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Hi Wendy.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I saw you on your bike today.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: With Mikey?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Nobody.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Mikey Williams?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: We were just riding around.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Weightless almost -- as if I were seeing my own memories of being a girl. There was something internal about it.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Mom. Are you ok?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Wendy, of course. I'm sorry. You must think I'm ripe to be checked into Silver Meadows.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: You're not a psycho!

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: The people at Silver Meadows aren't psychos.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I know. They're rich drug addicts and celebrities. When I saw James Taylor there, and --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: We've been through this Wendy James Taylor was actually at that clinic up near Boston.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Well, I saw what I saw, and if you don't want to believe me --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Oh Wendy.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: They need the money for my band uniform at school.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I thought you quit the band - I never hear you practice anymore.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I don't really need to practice. I just play a few notes, you know, so I thought maybe I'd stay in.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Well, I'm sure your father and I would love to hear what you're playing these days. Maybe after dinner.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: We're going to the Halford's. The number's on the calendar in the kitchen. We should be home around 11.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Is it a big party? A big neighborhood party?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I suppose. Why?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Just curious. If there's a problem, I guess I'll just call you there to interrupt.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: What sort of problems are you planning exactly?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Oh I thought I'd steal the station wagon, drive up to a commune. Or set the house on fire. You know.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Just bundle up. It's supposed to freeze tonight. We'll see you in the morning.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I don't like coffee.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: It'll warm you up.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Please don't.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: It's not a bother.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: I insist.  Don't touch them.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: It's really quite all right.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Thanks again. For the dinner.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Thanks for eating it. I don't know why I even pretend I can cook.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I used to know how to cook.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: It's not like we're too busy.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm thinking of going back to school.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Social work?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: How'd you know?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Educated guess.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm that predictable? No, you don't have to answer that. It's just that with the kids almost grown --

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: You don't have to apologize. I'm too much of a cynic. You actually seem to be trying to figure things out -- don't mind me.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Here you are.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Thanks for the lift. If the bike's any bother--

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: None at all. I'll leave it in front of your garage. Happy Thanksgiving.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Elena. Elena Hood, am I right?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Reverend Edwards. Philip Edwards. You came by and checked out the congregation a couple of times last year.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Yes, it was -- I ended up --

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: No need to make excuses --

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: It's been a tremendously transformative year -- maybe a little controversial of course, but we're breaking down the old Unitarian barriers --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I suppose my reluctance was the group aspect of it -- I've never been much of a joiner, although I still consider myself a somewhat religious person --

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Well I of course flatter myself that our church is not exactly what most people would call organized religion -- at times it's the disorganization that's liberating -- and of course I've begun to minister much more in what one might call therapeutic environments, in small groups, and one on one, couples --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: My daughter. I haven't been on a bike for years.  When was the last time you rode a bike?

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: They say you never forget.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Forget what?

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Forget how to ride a bike.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: In many ways, the church-bound tradition of the father, son, and holy ghost is simply a version of the parent-child-adult triad within us all. It's a primitive set of symbols for our inner psychology.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You're saying that Christ is the child, and --

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: -- And God the angry parent, and the Spirit the hope of an integrated adult self.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: All well and good -- But tell me again what is it exactly that you believe in?

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: You ask what the point is?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Self-realization. Ministering to help people reach their fullest potential. Would you believe me if I told you I want you to see yourself reach your fullest potential and self-realization?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I would say it sounds like you're trying to get me into bed.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: If that's a potential you see yourself fulfilling... I mean...  My, I sound a bit --

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm sorry. That was stupid of me. I didn't mean to be so rude.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: You weren't. You actually, for some reason, you have the effect on me of making me feel just a tiny bit ashamed of myself.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: But not too ashamed.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Now you are being rude.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: And you're still trying to get me into bed.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Ouch.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: I'm afraid she's something of a gossip, isn't she?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm afraid people around here provide her with quite a bit to gossip about.  Take care.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: That I will indeed.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Reverend Edwards.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Perhaps you might find it in your heart to call me Philip?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You're here... I'm a bit surprised.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Sometimes the shepherd needs the company of the sheep.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm going to try hard not to understand the implications of that simile.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Arise and shine, young Hood.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I hope you changed the water in that bong from last night.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: The water, as you call it, is a special mixture of amaretto and Ben&Ben blended for just the exact chemical interaction with the last of our precious Thai stick.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Waste not Master Hood -- that was $20 for the bag.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Man, Francis, you are one drug addled elitist freak, and when the revolution comes I do not want to be lined up with you and shot, 'cause you're fucking ripe for political reeducation, you know, like in the fields.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Paul, cancel your mental appointments, baby. What are you, like still stoned from last night?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I gotta get to English class.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No more man. I'm about to drop as it is.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: See ya.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Paul, let me enlighten you about something. You and I exist on two opposite sides of a great existential divide, that being your pathetic virginity on the one hand and my astonishing number of sexual conquests on the other. I'm off to get laid. See you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Flame on, asshole.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: And remember, with your erogenous zones lubricated as such with the mighty herb, do not attempt terrestrial contact with members of the opposite sex -- because you drone on like a motherfucker when you're stoned.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How can you do that man?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Do what?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sleep all day. I mean, look, it's already getting dark outside, and you're just getting up.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Um, Libbets Casey.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Aha! I could sense the vibe.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Am I right or am I right?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Shit. You're not planning --

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: My man, I speak to you solely as a comrade in arms offering unconditional aid. I've been giving this one a lot of thought, and I believe that the two of you together might just reach that higher ground that --

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: You oughtta read this Hood, Nixon, our leader, all ye need know about the travails of life. Check out the Checkers speech stuff.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Francis. You gonna leave the seeds in there? In the binding like that?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: All will be revealed, baby.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Moisture! Moisture!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And whence has yon virginal maiden absconded?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Like into one of the other 20 or so bathrooms they've got in this place.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Check it out. Not for the faint of heart.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Pharmaceutical! You are a god.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: One for you and one for me.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Awesome sleet and rain.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Major.

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Howdy there. You, young knight. Can you check on the mead? Can you sally forth and secure us some more mead?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Everything's gonna freeze, the big freeze.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Yeah, Paul, are you gonna get home okay?

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: No candy for me?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Groovy.  Young master of the revels, a treat for our hostess?

turns.speaker: FRANCIS
turns.text: Come on Paulie, share the wealth. You copped 'em from her mom's stash anyway.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Let's see!

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Jesus, Jim!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sorry honey. Hell, we've got to trade this thing in for a normal bed.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Just be careful.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You notice anything with Mikey lately? The kid seemed a little out of it tonight, eh?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Tonight? Jim, he's been out of it since he was born.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hell, I guess he takes after me, huh?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Hey.  I'll take this stuff.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You going to tell dad?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Would it matter?  And what's that?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You know, it's the whip -- the one uncle Frank got me from Mexico.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: It's not packed with explosives, is it?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Play with the whip.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Um, Libbets. Hey, Dostoyevsky, I'm also really a fan, and what you were saying, you know, have you ever read The Idiot?

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: The Idiot?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If you liked Notes from Underground, you'll love The Idiot.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Great, thanks for the tip.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The Idiot.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Frankie opens them with his teeth.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hey, it's a sellable skill.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, uh, I don't, it's really --

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Maybe you should have just a half.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Thanks for the advice dad.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You know Libbets, I really feel, you know, like a real connection to you --

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Yeah but you don't even know me really.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sure I do, you know, like your aura. That you give off.

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: My what?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's like very positive, and I feel a real special feeling, because you really --

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: And I have a special feeling too, because I do. It's special.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You do? I'm glad. Because I feel for you --

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: And I have a feeling for you too, because you're just like -- I feel for you like you're -- you're just like --

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Right. Cool. So, how about we take a bath together?

turns.speaker: LIBBETS
turns.text: Hah hah you're funny. A bath. Like a brother and sister. Oh man, I'm so wasted.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm in love with Libbets Casey.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Yeah, well, you've been in love with like every other girl here, I was wondering when you'd get around to Libbets.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's beyond mere physical attraction.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: That's good, because I don't think Libbets is capable of the sex act.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Truly? Do speak.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: My diagnosis is messed in the head. A poor little rich girl -- I mean check out the jeans and fur look. And lend your ears to this brutality. Like her mom and step dad and her step-sisters are going to Switzerland to ski over Thanksgiving break -- and like they didn't invite her!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How do you know this shit?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: They did it last year too. It's like traditional or something. They've got this humongoid Park Ave apartment and she just holes up there with a wad of cash.  Aren't the hugely wealthy sad?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You think Francis is going to beat me to the punch here?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Since he sleeps with every girl you ever show an interest in, why don't you just keep your Libbets thing a secret from him?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Good thinking Marge.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Stupid!  Is Wendy Hood your girlfriend?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Who said so?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: No one.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I don't have a girlfriend.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Mikey?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Geometry?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Sure, anything but this English.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Why are you so good at math but not in English?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I'm not good at math. Just geometry.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Out.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: It's freezing.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Yeah. When it freezes, I guess that means the molecules are not moving. So when you breathe, there's nothing in the air, you know, to breathe in to your body. The molecules have stopped. So it's clean.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Want some gum?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Sure.  Twinkie?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I'm chewing.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Did you tell Sandy?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Tell Sandy? What?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I don't ever want to see you.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Then why'd you come after me?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: You have to follow me?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I dunno. I --

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: See, no one's here. Maybe you want to go to the basement?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Maybe we can just watch some TV.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: There's a TV in the basement.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Maybe we can mess around. You know, only if you want to...

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Why did you -- with Sandy?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You like him? He worships you.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Wow!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Wendy!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: When worlds collide.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: 4:30 movie. When Worlds Collide.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You're parents at that party?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Yeah. Yours?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You get in trouble?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Maybe. Can't really tell yet.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I'm sorry if I got you into trouble. Maybe we don't have to, you know... unless you really want to.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Charles.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Charles. Have you been keeping out of my shit? Have you refrained from entering the sacred precincts of my room?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I have not touched your sh--  Stuff. You watching this?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Watching what?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Nixon, doofus! It's incredible. He should be shot.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hello, Charles.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Greetings, Charles.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How are the parental units functioning these days?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Dad's like doing his Up With People routine, mom hasn't been saying much.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't know. Dad seems a little weird.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Yeah well wait till mom opens her mouth.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: May I operate your telephonic apparatus?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Why don't you use the phone downstairs?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Calling an individual, Charles, in New York. Confirming a social outing for Friday night.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Can I come?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's a one-on-one kind of date thing.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: With who?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Her name's Libbets.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Libbets? What kind of a name is Libbets?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Hood residence.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Charles, what time is it?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Is this Charles?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Um, ten-o-five. Why? Where are you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm, uh, in the midst of a moral dilemma. And I was wondering, because I know you're a very moral person, and --

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Shit. I can't really talk about it. I guess I better get to the train.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What are you doing at home on a Friday night?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I have plans.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Hey Wendy.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Hey Sandy.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Mikey was looking for you.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Yeah? See ya.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Well, you can...

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Hey Sandy, what were you blowing up out there? Your mom was pretty p.o.'d.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: All my model planes.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: The ones you built?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: They were old. And they couldn't fly anyhow. I'm going to get a radio-controlled airplane at Christmas, and then I'll stuff it full of m-80s and then fly it into Mrs. Burgess's English class and blow it up.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I have to go to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Sandy, you scared the shit out of me.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Just thought I'd stop by.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Mike's out -- I think he went to Silver Meadow to see if you were hanging around there.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Are you his girlfriend?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: He's dead.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: If it wasn't raining we could take him outside and blow him up.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: He wouldn't blow up. He'd just get all mangled or twisted.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Well.  It looks like someone got to his private parts before us.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Communist Viet Cong.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: They left it in the jungle.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: We -- we have to go to the guest room. We can't stay in here. What if Mikey? My parents?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Don't worry about them. They're at that party, getting drunk and falling all over each other and making jokes about McGovern and stuff.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Want a drink?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Vodka?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: You never tasted the stuff?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: It feels warm.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: One more shot?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: Have you ever had a nocturnal emission?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: That's the name for when you wake up and find this little pool of sticky stuff, like after a sexy dream.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: That's nice. Are you drunk?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I don't know. How do I know?

turns.speaker: WENDY
turns.text: I don't know either. You spin around, when you lie down.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: That's all, for now.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Didn't want to miss anything.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: Detective Dormer's not leaving for a few hours.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: Maybe you could drive him to Spencer's.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Just after Leland Street.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: What's that, then?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Nice kid.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: Got a love affair with police work. Drives me crazy with it.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So far.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: What's the D.A. got them on?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Four unwarranted shootings, witness intimidation, and cocaine theft.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: That's I.A.'s pit bull.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: Wants me to keep him posted on all your movements up here.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: And then I lost him.  In the fog.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: About how long 'til you heard the suspect's second shot?

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: Will, you can't blame yourself.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I had him!

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: It's only gonna make you crazy.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have to get back.

turns.speaker: CHIEF NYBACK
turns.text: Too bad...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: My partner...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Detective Eckhart!  I know!  Welcome to Nightmute!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You did your homework, Officer.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Actually...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Guess that's what they call Alaskan hospitality.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Don't worry about him...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Don't give misdemeanors a bad rap.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But they're so boring.  All small stuff.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's all about the small stuff.  Small lies.  Small mistakes.  Small oversights. People give themselves away in a traffic violation just as much as they do in a murder case.  It's human nature.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Typical seventeen year-old.  She went to a party Friday night?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Down at a local dive the kids like to hang out in.
